A set $M$ with a law of composition $\sigma: M \times M \longrightarrow M$ is called a monoid if $\sigma$ is associative and $M$ admits a unit element with respect to $\sigma$.
Two cycles $(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r})$ and $(y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s})$ are called disjoint if the sets $\{x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\}$ and $\{y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s}\}$ have no elements in common.
Does the concept of a/an Monoid need to be defined for a definition of a/an Disjoint Cycles to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of Disjoint Cycles pertains to the arrangement of elements in cycles such that no elements overlap between the cycles. This concept is purely combinatorial and relates to the properties of sets and their elements. It involves checking whether two sets of elements (cycles) share any common elements.

On the other hand, a Monoid is an algebraic structure consisting of a set equipped with an associative binary operation and an identity element. This concept is foundational in abstract algebra but does not directly influence the definition or understanding of Disjoint Cycles.

Therefore, understanding or defining Disjoint Cycles does not require the concept of a Monoid. Disjoint Cycles can be fully understood and defined using basic set theory and combinatorics, without any reference to the algebraic structure of a Monoid.
